newsitem.title: SWEDEN: Swedish Riksbank cuts repo rate to 4.10 pct.
newsitem.headline: Swedish Riksbank cuts repo rate to 4.10 pct.

text.p: Sweden's central bank, the Riksbank, on Tuesday cut its key interest rate, the repo rate, by 25 basis points to 4.10 percent as widely expected in the market.
As announced by the bank, the reverse repurchase operation will run for three weeks from December 18 to January 8 to cover the holiday period.
It was released at the same time as the Riksbank's last inflation report for the year which painted a bullish picture for the next two years.
This was the 25th cut this year to the repo, which is the Riksbank's main tool for controlling money market liquidity.
The repo rate, the central rate in a three tier system, started the year at 8.91 percent but the central bank has pursued an aggressive monetary policy.

The cut was expected by the financial markets, especially after a fall of 0.3 percent in consumer price figures released last week showed Sweden was in a negative annualised inflation trend for the second consecutive month.

In a Reuters poll, all 14 economists questioned expected a repo cut. Nine forecast a lowering of 25 basis points, two a cut of 20 basis points and one a 35 basis points drop. The others forecast ranges between 15 to 35 basis points.
This is the third time the Riksbank had lowered the repo rate by 25 basis points.
The last move was on November 26.
The Riksbank last lowered its two other key rates, the deposit and lending rates, on December 5 when the bank trimmed both by 50 basis points to 3.75 percent and 5.25 percent respectively.
